4427840/4349265/4440069.title: Stories Relating to Denis Browne
4427840/4349265/4440069.text:
Denis Browne was the high sheriff of the county and he had a share in a Belfast mill and Denis used to go around the country buying yarn. All the people used go to the markets and sell it to him and he was very nice to deal with. He was a very good judge in buying it and he was a very rough looking man and he was about twenty two stone in weight. Denis Browne once hanged his own nephew who was a leader in the white boys. This boy's name was also Browne and he was the finest looking boy you ever looked at. When Denis was hanging
(continues on next page)

4427840/4349266/4440070.title: Stories Relating to Denis Browne
4427840/4349266/4440070.text:
(continued from previous page)
the boy the rope broke and the boy said my life is my own yet Denis and he also spat in the face of Denis. it is, said Denis if there is not a rope in Castlebar to hang you. This boy's sister went over to England andshe got a reprieve for her brother but, Denis heard this and he had the boy hanged before she came back.



There was no more cruel character in this locality than Denis Browne. Denis was an uncle of the Browns in Brownstown and he used hang all the people he used catch a hold of. One day a woman from
(continues on next page)

4427840/4349268/4440071.title: Stories Relating to Denis Browne
4427840/4349268/4440071.text:
(continued from previous page)
off in their chariot and rode straight up to the convent in Claremorris and asked for Denis Browne. The reply that came was that he was not in. The priest shouted and said " send him out at once." So Denis came and the priest put him down on his two knees and made him walk on his knees out to the middle of the town and made him swear never to kill anyone from that on. So that was the end of Denis Browne.Pupil's name Kathleen Hynes Petter Fahy Mountain, Ballindine age about 73 yrs.Denis Browne was going to dinner with Lord Oranmore and Browne at the entrance of the residence there lived a widow and her son. So Denis Browne passed in the avenue the

4427840/4349271/4440072.title: Stories Relating to Denis Browne
4427840/4349271/4440072.text:
(continued from previous page)
leap and jumped the river. From that day to this day that place is called. The Connaught man's leap" which no man ever jumped before or after that.One day Denis Browne was in Ballinrobe and he was hanging the people. He was engaged to a girl named Kegan and this day he was after hanging her father. When she heard that her father was being hanged she said that she would have revenge on him They had a draper shop at this time and in it were some large rolls of tweed. At noon as she was going to her dinner she saw Denis Browne and she invited him to dinner. She let on that she was inviting him unknown to her mother. Their house was a three storey house

4427840/4349275/4440075.title: Stories Relating to Denis Browne
4427840/4349275/4440075.text:
(continued from previous page)
After that he never hanged anyone. There is a family of Banes yet in that village who are also smiths.

4427842/4349660/4440683.title: Games
4427842/4349660/4440683.text:
(continued from previous page)
fifth hop out again pick up the slate and hop back again. Some children very often fails to do so.



Denis Browne lived in Claremorris where the convent is now. He lived in the time of the Penials Laws. He was high sheriff of Mayo. He used kill people and priests. He had his cart in the middle of the town where the pump is now. He used to hang the people from that cart.There are many old stories told about him. Once he was to have three men from Kilvive hung at twelve o clock the next
(continues on next page)

4427842/4349704/4440686.title: Denis Browne
4427842/4349704/4440686.text:
(continued from previous page)
judgement.



There was a woman living near Garda [?] named Mac Quillan.  She had a son that wouldn't do anything he was told to do.  He was a great smith but seldom he used to work one day she went into Denis Browne complaining about her son.  She thought he would only tell him to do what he would be told to do.Denis Browne told her to send in her son to him and he would tell him to do what he would be told to do.  She
(continues on next page)

4427842/4349715/4440948.title: Denis Browne
4427842/4349715/4440948.text:
(continued from previous page)
brought in her son to him. He brought out her son and hung him to a tree. He was her only son. She went daft after that.

4427853/4350774/4453291.title: Denis Brown
4427853/4350774/4453291.text: There was a man once going visiting to a cousin's house. He had a long way to go and he had to go along the road, when suddenly he came to a dark place. He got afraid. A big black dog, and three others came out on the road. The man asked the dogs who they were. The dogs said "We are Denis Brown and his three hang men." The dogs had chains on them. the man went to this cousin's house and did not come home until morning.

4427853/4350787/4453363.title: Denis Browne
4427853/4350787/4453363.text: Denis Browne lived in Claremount in a  room in the Convent. The room in which he lived can not be opened. A priest and an other man went to the room and the priest said mass there. During the mass, a big black dog came out of the room and the priest asked him was he Denis Browne and he said he was. The room is still there and no body goes near it or goes into it. He was High-Sheriff of County Mayo. He was also a member of Parliament and voted for the Union. There is a field near the Convent called "Cnoc na Crouche" in which he had his gallows.

4427853/4350788/4453366.title: Denis Browne
4427853/4350788/4453366.text: There was once a man and he used to call Denis Browne Donnac an Builge but he took no notice of him because he though he had no since. So he said he would find if he had sence. He got a handful of silver and a handful of coppers, and he asked him which would he take, He said he would take the coppers because they would buy tobacco. He knew then he had no sense. There was once a man who used to call Denis Browne Donnah an Bhuilg. He took no notice of him, because he thought he had no sense. Denis Browne said he would find out if he he had sense. He got a handful of silver and a handful of coppers, and he asked him which would he take.The man said he would the coppers because they would buy tobacco. Denis Browne knew then he had no sense.

4427853/4350789/4453377.title: Denis Browne
4427853/4350789/4453377.text:
There was a man named Michael Prendergast living in Ballygown in the place where Ivan Curran lives now.He was a man who feared no danger. He did not fear Denis Browne. Somebody advised him not to say anything about Browne or else he could have him put to death. In the meantime someone informed of Prendergast and told Browne all Prendergast had said about him. Browne then sent four soldiers for his arrest which they succeeded in doing. They brought the prisoner forward. Browne  on hearing of his arrival told the soldiers to bring him in to the place where he as seated.Browne then questioned him about all he said about him, or was he aware that he could have him executed before sunset on that
(continues on next page)

4427853/4350791/4453384.title: Denis Brown and His Hangmen
4427853/4350791/4453384.text: There was once a man going to his neighbour's house visiting, when he came to a dark spote on the road. He got afraid of it when suddenly a big black dog and three others came out on the road. He asked them who they were and they said that they were Denis Brown, and his hang men. He saw chains on them, and he was afraid after that.

4428071/4375019/4457331.title: Soap the Rope
4428071/4375019/4457331.text:
The chief priest hanger was Seán Browne  or "Seán - na - Sagart" as he was called. A priest was being hung in Castlebar once and the rope broke. Another rope was found and this time Seán shouted "Soap the rope". The rope was soaped and the priest was hung. Ever since Seán went by the name "Soap the Rope". One day he gave a feast. All the English Protestant gentry of Mayo attended. In the middle of the feasting he showed his guests a rope
(continues on next page)

5215809/5213893/5221505.title: Denis Brown
5215809/5213893/5221505.text:
Once upon a time Denis Brown lived in Mountbrown in a castle. He was a very wicked man and he used to be on the look out of men to hang them. One day he saw a man passing by his castle and he prepared to follow. He followed him and had a big rope with him. He could not get the man Then Denis Brown returned to his castle. He was called also Denis of the roape. When he returned to his castle a gentleman was outside the door. Denis opened the door and let the gentleman in. When Denis Brown went in and he began looking at papers that were in his pockets. That meant that he could kill anyone he would see passing by. The gentleman took the paper out of Denis Brown's hand and read it. Denis tried to get the pass again but the gentleman would not let it go. Then Denis
(continues on next page)

5215809/5213936/5221623.title: Denis Brown
5215809/5213936/5221623.text:
Denis Brown was a good man before the rebellion of 1798. He was favourable both to Protestant and Catholics and any one that wanted to speak to him could go to the Castle in  Mount brown at certain hours.At the beginning of the rebellion Denis Browne heard that the rebels were coming and he went away towards Ballinrobe on horseback. When he was up near Killawalla he got afraid that his enemies were (afraid) catching up to him. He came off his horse and he (crossed) exchanged his black suit with  a beggar-man. When the rebels reached Castle in Mountbrown
(continues on next page)

5215809/5214071/5221682.title: People Hanged by Denis Brown
5215809/5214071/5221682.text:
When Denis Brown lived in Mountbrown he had a castle with a hundred rooms in it. If you went in you could not make your way out again. There was a big lawn out in front of the castle. There were a lot of trees in this lawn. There was one big oak tree in the middle of the lawn and on that tree he used to hang the people that gave three cheers for the French. There was a man named Hastings who lived in Creagán Darach. He was hung in Barrack Hill in Westport for giving three cheers for the
(continues on next page)

5236078/5218411/5241045.title: Denis Brown
5236078/5218411/5241045.text:
There lived in an old Castle in the village of Mount Brown in the parish of Aughagower Denis Brown. He was a wicked old man. He used to hang men and priests on an ash tree near his house. Any one that would pass there used to hear noises and see lights in the Castle at late hours of the night. A man from the village was passing at a late hour one night and he saw a man dressed in white near where Denis used to hang people. He was very much afraid and he never passed there again at a late hour.



Long ago a man who lived near Castlebar came to visit he friends in Aughagower. He came on horse back he didnot leave for home until eleven o'clock
(continues on next page)

5215809/5231463/5265054.title: Denis Brown
5215809/5231463/5265054.text:
1) Denis Brown a very wicked man. He had a tree outside his castle and the curious thing about it was that no leaves grew on it. The tree is there yet. He used to hang people on this tree. Once upon a time a gentleman came to see his castle. When he came near the tree he saw bits of ropes around it. When he went into Denis Brown he asked him put all those bits of ropes around the tree. Denis gave him no answer but took him there and then and choked him.The castle was very big. It is said there was a room for every-day in the year in it. It had very small windows in it. But it is down now. The stones of the
(continues on next page)

5215809/5231465/5265057.title: Denis Brown and the Tramp
5215809/5231465/5265057.text:
Once upon a time when Denis Brown was living in Mountbrown a tramp passed by. The tramp saw a nice shirt out on the bush. He was admiring it and wondering at it because it was a new shirt and he never saw a shirt like it before. Then Denis Brown called him in so the tramp went in. Denis asked him was he going to Castlebar and he said he was Then he asked him would he deliver the letter to the warder in the jail and to give him a shilling. Then the tramp started his journey to Castlebar. On his way to Castlebar he met another tramp and he asked this tramp was he going
(continues on next page)

5215809/5231778/5265842.title: Denis Brown's Castle
5215809/5231778/5265842.text:
Denis Brown's CastleLong ago when Denis Brown was living in Mountbrown he had a fine castle with one hundred and one rooms. Many persons used to go to see the fine castle and when they would go into the rooms they could not get out because every place they would walk around they would see themselves in a mirror. There were four or five rooms that were locked up and it is said that no one ever opened those doors. Some one did open one of the doors and it is said that the person was taken and never seen or heard of after that again. It is said that some people when passing this big castle saw
(continues on next page)
